review:
We have been enthusiastic purchasers of Leapfrog products for many years.  My three boys, ages 9, 7 and 5 have loved the games for the Leapster Explorer and the Leapster before that.  Sadly, after purchasing the LeapPad2 at an American Base Commissary overseas, I learned that Leapfrog does not allow individuals to purchase apps online for their LeapPad products from overseas - even if one has an American Military/Diplomatic post office address in the United States.  Specifically, they do not allow for input of APO/DPO addresses when you try to input your credit card information on their App Store online.

For those of us who serve overseas, this is unfortunately a familiar problem.  I thought I would be able to correct it with a friendly phone call to Leapfrog customer service.  Here's what happened instead.  I spent 33 minutes waiting on hold for Leapfrog customer service on an international phone call before I finally gave up.  The second day, I spent another 15 minutes on hold before reaching a representative who told me that they do not support credit card payments online for credit cards with APO/DPO billing addresses.  I figured that she didn't have the power to do anything and politely asked to speak to a manager.

Denise the Customer Service Manager replied that the company indeed would not support an APO/DPO credit card and could not take the order manually with a credit card number over the phone.  After noting that Leapfrog sold these app-dependent products overseas at locations where online service is necessary, she apologized and said there was nothing to be done but buy a "Prepaid App Card" at a local retailer like Walmart or Toys R Us.  Of course, these stores don't exist in the country in which I live which Denise verified.

Denise said that she would talk to her superiors and either call or e-mail the next day with a solution.  But you guessed it - she did not - which is why this negative review exists.  I cannot recommend that Americans serving overseas purchase this new generation of Leapfrog products.  This is doubly a shame because I think the product is good and Leapfrog's website manager could correct this problem in about 15 minutes if the company really wanted to.

*EDIT! This was a 5 star review, BUT the rechargeable batteries is what sold this for me, but after only a few months, the battery pack quit working, LeapFrog is refusing to honor the warranty, and they suggested I repurchase the $70-80 rechargeable battery pack. NO THANK YOU. We'll take apart the battery packs and just recharge the batteries inside with our own wall charger. There's a YouTube video to show you how to do it.

I LOVE that this particular package came with the rechargeable batteries. It's what sold it, to be honest. Our old one (same model) finally quit working after 5 years of sometimes rough handling (thrown on floor in frustration, tossed into bedroom, stepped on, etc.) It saw two children through rather rough patches of 2-4 year old child use. We happily purchased this new one and has honestly paid for itself with the ability to plug it in, and as our 2nd 4 year old can plug it in herself, she's taking better care if it than she did with her sister's old one.

My daughter used this most when she was four and five. Every now and then she will still get it back out (she's 7 now), even though we haven't got any new games for it in a couple years. She never spent a lot of time on it. She got a little bored after about 15 minutes or so, but still continued to use it. I think most of the games are challenging enough for the age group. Now that there are better kid appropriate tablets available (like the Kids Fire--no I don't make money off promoting it), I would probably get that instead. There are more gaming options in Freetime (for the Fire) and the games are free (at least for a year, not sure what the renewal price is). Most of the games for the LeapPad are affordable and able to be downloaded directly to the device, which is nice, so you don't have a bunch of cartridges getting lost. I like that most of the games are educational. It makes you feel less guilty for letting your kids have screen time. :)

I bought this for my 3 year old daughter for Christmas and she has absolutely loved it. She wanted her own tablet like her big sissy had, so we decided on this one because of the age appropriate design, content and ease of use. It came with the battery pack for extended play if we are going to be away from home for a while, as well as a plug in battery. I'm glad all this came together instead of having to buy it separately. The apps that came with the tablet were great starting apps for her to get used to the tablet and she loves the drawing app the most. It also has a camera, and calculator. The front facing camera is great for her to take pics of herself and not have to worry about coordinating the back facing camera. The front facing camera is very easy for her to use. You can also add effects to the pics. The LeapFrog leap pad comes with a USB that you plug directly into your computer and through this you register and can buy games and apps and download them directly to your device, which is a very easy process. We have downloaded lots of games that she loves like Little Mermaid, Bubble Guppies, Astro Blast, Sesame Street and a few learning games which have really helped her with her vocabulary and letter recognition. The sound is great and is easy to adjust. What I love the most is the durability and rugged construction of the device. She has dropped it twice and there was no damage to the device at all. She is 3 so she isn't always the most responsible with her gadgets, which is why we went with this device over anything too expensive. The screen is still scratch free and no cracks or chips are present anywhere. Overall, this has been a fantastic learning tool for my little one and for the price has given her her very own tablet that provides hours of fun and learning on car rides, doctors visits, or just playing it at home. We love the tablet and would recommend it to anyone with a child around the 3-6 age range.

Apparently it voids the warranty...kids can easily crack the screen just so know! Also after the company had me erase all the apps on my leap pad they refused to replace them! Yes, I will repeat that, the company instructed me on doing a repair, that ended up erasing all the apps on the leap pad, including the apps that came with the leappad when we bought it.  I could easily get the apps I purchased back, however the apps that came with the leappad when I got it new were gone and I was literally told by a supervisor that it was my fault because I was the one who asked them for assistance to fix a problem I was having with the leap pad (that was only 4 months old)! After spending hours on the phone over a 3 day span, I was told they would NOT replace the apps THEY had me erase! It was 11 apps all together they had me erase and then refused to replace....I AM AN HONEST PERSON AND WOULD ONLY EVER WRITE A REVIEW LIKE THIS IF I REALLY FELT I NEEDED TO TRY AND SAVE OTHER PARENTS FROM EXPERIENCING THE MOST HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED FROM ANY COMPANY EVER....AND I AM IN THE SERVICE INDUSTRY!

Pros:
Some of the software cartridges for the system are very good (like the Mr. Pencil).
Simple enough for young children (3 years) to figure out and learn something from it.

Cons:
Provided rechargeable batteries lose charge capability awfully quick.  Had two leap-pads and within a few months of light use, the rechargeables started failing.
Something is up with the cartridge slot.  On both units, again within a few months, I have to insert the cartridges like this was a Nintendo (blow in the slot, insert slowly and hope it works).
Loss of audio on one of the devices after 6 months.
Random device death on the other after 9 months.

Notes:
- Leapfrog replaced the device that had the audio failure with no trouble whatsoever
- I did not ask them to replace the other.  We moved on from leappads mostly because I wasn't pleased with most of the other software and when the replacement leap pad had the same cartridge reader slot issue... I just wrote it off the leap pads entirely..

Very durable, it has been dropped several times and although we have a rubber case around it, it hasn't seemed to bother the LeapPad.  I highly recommend the rechargeable battery -- I wish I had bought it right away with the LeapPad but figured regular batteries would also last awhile, but I was wrong.  It is definitely better to be able to charge it, and the rechargeable battery lasts a very long time which is great.  I highly recommend the LeapPad2!

I saw this in a local store for 50% off, and I couldn't pass it up.  My son is just shy of 2.5 and received it today as an early Christmas/desperation gift because his dad and I were out of options to entertain him this weekend.  You may snark at this, or you may nod and laugh, but it is what it is.  Needless to say, he loves the gift.  He quite literally could not put it down, and threw an epic tantrum when we made him take a break.

Prior to seeing this in the store, I had no intention of buying him any kind of tablet and I had no knowledge of this product.  I must say I made a good choice on a whim.  I don't usually make toy purchases without reading reviews first, but this tablet is a great toy for kids who just don't get much out of the other toddler tech toys like Leap Frog's "My Own Laptop", which is rated for 3-5 years according to the package.  We had that one, but my son was only interested in it for about 5 minutes.

What I like about this tablet is that it DOES NOT HAVE WIFI.  Some parents may want WIFI, but I think for a kid this young it is highly unnecessary and even a bad idea.  There is simply nothing he can do to get himself or us into trouble with this.  No chance of buying apps without permission, no stumbling on websites he's not allowed to see, no advertisements.  Perfect.  The games themselves are pretty pricey, but I like the cartridge format.  I realize you can buy them in the Leap Frog app store, but I like the cartridges for resale options if my son doesn't like them.  So far I have purchased 3 games, 2 of which he has opened, and 1 of which he is gaga over.  I also purchased him an ebook and a music album from the online store.  I love that you can use Paypal to purchase the apps.  It makes it super easy.

The stylus is handy and helps my son learn to grip a pencil the correct way.  Already on the first day I have seen improvement there.  The touchscreen does work without the stylus for most applications.  My son is a little rough with the stylus.  If you have a younger kid, you might invest in a screen protector.  I intend to get one to protect the screen.  We also have the gel skin, which I recommend if you have this "power" version with the battery packs, as it could get annoying to have to remove the skin every time you change batteries.  I'm not sure the skin will protect in the case of drops, but it will protect against scratches and other misuse.

The interface is very easy. My son grasps the concept of the games very well, and although he can't play all the games without help, I'm sure it won't be long before he masters them.  For this reason, I recommend sticking to the 3 year age recommendation.  It really would have been better at 3.  My son is smart enough, but not really mature enough to use this.  There were several reviewers who stated that they gave this to their kid younger than 3, so I took the chance.  I wish I would have waited.

Startup of the tablet is fast.  You do have to choose your profile every time you sign in, even if you only have 1 profile loaded.  The apps also load fast, which is good since my son has zero patience.

The apps included with the tablet are sort of lame.  He does like PetPad quite a bit.  I'm not sure the calculator or the clock will ever get used.  The notepad seems like it would be for kids that would be much older, and would no longer find this tablet entertaining.  The camera is a nice feature, and one I'm sure my son will enjoy once he figures it out. The art studio appeared to be missing until we hooked up the tablet to the computer and downloaded it.  I'm not sure we will ever use the calendar either.  We also got to chose 1 free app, which ended up being a Scout and Violet game about emotions, the only one available for my son's age group.  There were 3 to choose from, and the other 2 were for older kids.  I'm not sure about the ebook, but the music I bought is pretty good and he likes it.  I think he will get more out of the ebook later.

The batteries seem to charge pretty fast.  There is no battery indicator, which is a little worrisome if we are traveling with this.

Overall this device seems like a solid toy, and I think we are really going to enjoy it for waits at the doctor's office, long car rides, and times like this weekend when we just couldn't find anything else that would occupy him.  Prior to using this he had played on my iPhone and iPad several times, but only in situations where I was desperate to keep his attention (restaurants with long waits) and I never liked handing him something that expensive.  I have resisted buying him tech toys up until about 6 months ago, and I cannot justify buying him a grownup tablet at this age.  I feel this is a good compromise.  It's going to be hard to keep him off of it.

One more thing.  If you are buying this for Christmas, I recommend unpacking it and setting everything up beforehand.  My little guy could barely contain himself while I inserted the batteries and downloaded everything.  (downloads are kind of slow for larger files, i.e. games)  You'd be smart to get everything set up and charged before the handoff.  It's going to be a showstopper for sure.  We are now glad we did it before the big day, as it would have distracted from any other gifts and activities on Christmas!

I want to give it four stars, but I have to go with three because we've had too many "hiccups" in our first few days with the device. First, our daughter is left-handed. Both the LeapPad and its games were designed for right-handed children. There are two options for attaching the stylus, both are on the right side. What this means is that in portrait mode, the cord from the stylus either hangs diagonally across the screen or awkwardly behind or in front of the bottom buttons, and the cord is too short either way (I'll replace it with something, but that shouldn't be necessary). In landscape mode, using the stylus with a left hand covers up much of the screen as the games are laid out to be right-hand friendly (meaning stylus activity is often on the right side of the screen). If this were the first LeapPad to be designed I could almost forgive this short-sightedness, but a quick google shows customers have had this complaint for years. I find it really annoying that the problem still exists.

Second, forgive me but I have an old laptop, running XP. You have to install the LeapFrog software on your computer to load anything onto the device. I would have appreciated a warning that the software was going to (1) not function, and (2) force me to spend half a day trying to repair all the damage it did to my formerly well-oiled machine. It caused a lot of problems (I can't even shut my machine down now, or run a system restore.) I'm going to have to borrow a computer anytime I need to load stuff onto/remove stuff from the LeapPad or shop on the LeapFrog store. And to think I didn't want WiFi.

Third, I would like to see a little more control over the device preferences. In some situations, the screen is entirely too bright and it is not adjustable, and the lowest volume setting is anything but quiet. There's an art app and a pet app that come pre-installed, both of which have tutorial-type directions that NEVER STOP. It tells you how to play once, then any time the stylus is motionless for two seconds, the voice starts up again. It's a little confusing for a three year old, way annoying for mommy and totally unnecessary. I'm praying the purchased apps don't do the same thing.

The device is also capable of playing music, but you have to purchase an mp3 player for it. I think it was $5. I know the apps are expensive, but this really makes me feel like we're going to be nickel and dimed.

We got the LeapPad because we love the LeapFrog movies and expected to love the LeapPad apps as much. The experience has been a bigger letdown than I ever expected. I hope we grow to love it, and I'll update my review if my opinion changes one way or another.

By the way, if you're shopping for one, check prices whenever you can. I've been to this page four times in three days and the prices jump around between $50 and $80 quite often. Also, never pay full price for apps through the LeapFrog store. Sales rotate constantly.

*EDIT I forgot to mention, Alphabet Stew, one of the first apps we bought, which is similar to Boggle (find words in a grid of letters) is ...well, wrong. The very first puzzle we played denies "log" and "dam" are words. SO confusing and irresponsible for a game that's supposed to teach children! I'm afraid I'm going to have to remove a star for that one. I'm losing faith in this company.

I simply cannot praise this tablet enough. Every app has been perfect for helping my twins learn. Because of this toy, they know their upper and lower case letters and the sounds they make. They can count to 40. They can even read and spell a few words, and they are only three! We bought this for Christmas 2013 and they have held up through hundreds of drops, juice spills, being stepped on, etc. They do not have wifi access (but what three year old needs that?), but you can connect the device to your computer to download apps and see their progress. This actually turned out to be my favorite feature. The tablet has a built in camera, recorder, and art program and you can download their art, pictures, and videos. It is so fun to see the art and photography from a three year old mind, and they have made some really cool artwork! I debated and researched forever because the apps can be pricey and there are many tablets to choose from. The decision maker for me was the fact that every app is educational and can span a variety of ages. They have some free apps and some kid apps on my Kindle, but it is a toss up as to how much learning they get from them. I have not been disappointed in a single app, yet. If you want something for 2-6yr old kids, I recommend this one. I even find myself preaching it to strangers in the toy aisle! I would, however, get the rechargeable pack. These things have a battery life of about 4 hours, and we are still constantly charging them from all the use they get.

Okay, so this is actually our third LeapPad as the two older kids also have LeapPads.

First, the positives:  the kids enjoy playing on these, they don't love them, but they do like them.  They are especially useful on road trips where they can keep occupied for an hour or so.  Many of the apps/games are educational which is obviously a plus.  And you can plug the LeapPad into your PC to see what they have been playing and track their progress.  Some people may list as a negative, but I like there is no wifi or internet connectivity on this device.  They have plenty of years to play on the net....for now, I appreciate limited access to it.

Now the negatives:  the games/pass get expensive.  Yes, there are apps you can download for $3 or so.  But there are many for $20-$25, and some of them are glorified e-books.  We have three of these in our house, and two screens have now cracked, presumably during a drop.  Now, these were not abused, and not even used that much, and two of three screens....cracked.  LeapPads website clearly lists this product for 3-9 year olds.  If they have not been designed and proven to resist drops, then this is a MAJOR defect.  So, this alone would cause me not to purchase another one.  However, it gets worse.  The first one broke about 2 months after receiving it.  Contact LeapFrog and they responded that they don't have anything in stock to replace it, so contact vendor.  I thought, two months later on a Manufacturer issue, not a vendor issue, how could that fly??  Contacted amazon, and they sent a replacement LeapPad....wow, now that is top notch customer service!  Thanks, five stars to Amazon.  Fast forward to our third LeapPad purchase (we should have learned after the first crack)......and again about 2 months after purchase, cracked screen.  I contact LeapPad asking for a replacement screen, repair or replacement product.  They respond with an offer to purchase a discount LeapPad.  They state they do not cover accidents or misuse.......really, how is a 3-year old supposed to use this product??  It is going to get dropped, that is a fact.  If the screens are not durable enough to handle it, which they are not, they should be marketing this product for 9-12 year olds.  Bottom line is poor customer service, LeapPad doesn't stand behind their product, and I refuse to purchase another LeapFrog product ever again.  I am tired of companies making inferior products over in China, raking in a lot of money and not standing behind the product.

The Leappad 2 Power is functionally identical to the standard (and cheaper) Leappad 2 tablet, but for the inclusion of a rechargeable battery kit and charger that Leapfrog also sells separately. The compelling advantage of Leapfrog's kit is that the batteries can be recharged in the unit, unlike conventional AA rechargeable batteries, which would need to be removed first. While it seems a money grab initially, the design prevents the inadvertent (and unsafe) recharging of alkaline batteries. In a pinch, alkaline or rechargeable AA batteries can be swapped into the unit.

We bought the Leappad for our 4 year old son for Christmas. This is a great toy for the younger end of the recommended 4-9 year old age range. Older kids, or kids who've previously had much exposure to "grown-up" Apple or Android devices are unlikely to find this a compelling alternative. That said, all the content available for it is of good educational value, and without the advertising or in-app purchases so common on iOS and Android devices. Games and apps can be "installed" via interchangeable cartridges, or purchased on-line and downloaded into the unit's internal memory, which is sufficient to hold a couple dozen apps at the same time, and without risk of your little one losing the carts.

The overall build quality is excellent, with commendable display and sound quality, given the selling price. Both cameras are trash VGA resolution affars that perform atrociously in low light conditions, but are commendable relative to the selling price of the unit. The unit is also suitably ruggedized for the child demographic it is targeted at, and includes thoughtful design touches as a stylus that is tethered, and which easily stores in a niche on the side of the unit. Leapfrog sells a series of rubber cases for these that add an additional layer of protection inexpensively.

Our 6 year old son received the LeapPad2 Power for Christmas 2013. We chose LeapPad because the whole experience seems to be geared toward educational games and learning, it has a pretty huge library of games and apps, and it is a pretty decent value compared to some other similar kid's tablets.

While some of the WiFi enabled tablets looked pretty neat (giving the kid the ability to email you drawings, I think), we figured it would be overkill for our 6 year old's first tablet. We opted for the "Power" model with rechargeable batteries, because using the tablet in the car on long trips was a major reason we got him a tablet. We did not want to keep buying batteries whenever he was away from a power outlet.

The tablet came with only a tiny handful of apps and games. I was a little disappointed there was not more loaded on to it to begin with. Besides the camera, I think there was a doodle app, one game, and a bunch of useless things for kids like a notepad, etc. The games, books, and apps are a little more expensive than I thought they would be ($7 to $15 each). I really don't know how developers can create incredibly polished iPhone apps and charge $1 or $2 and Leap Frog's basic games cost $10. Could be due to licensing Disney characters.

I will say that there is ample memory on the device, making cartridges unnecessary. So glad we don't have to keep track of a dozen small plastic game cartridges!

I would say the device is pretty durable, but it does have some limitations. My son has dropped it a lot of times, and it keeps on working fine. However, I do think a soft, rubbery case is a good idea. Last week, my son told me that he broke the screen. It was shattered. I took a picture and sent it to Leap Frog support. They said they do not repair or replace screens, but they did offer me a 50% discount on a new unit. I think that's pretty fair, since it probably broke due to rough use (though my son tells me he wasn't being rough). We will be replacing it, since we probably paid the same for games and apps for the thing as we did for the device in the first place.

Overall, we have been pretty satisfied with the device (even though the screen failed). We let our son play on it for about an hour a day and he really enjoys it.

I bought this for my niece as a Christmas gift. It was fairly easy to set up and she (2 years) enjoyed it. Though it wasn't recommended for her age group, she seems to understand the mechanics well. Her favorite (stock, included on the tablet) application is the Art Studio (art doo-dee-doo, as she calls it) gives her endless hours of enjoyment. We did run into an issue with the tablet not booting up properly and requesting that it be plugged in to the PC for maintenance, but after it downloaded a fairly large file (90Mb) the tablet rebooted itself and it started working again. I'm a little disappointed that the applications are mostly geared to older kids, though I do understand she falls short of the target age range. Most applications are fairly expensive as well, but I knew that before I bought the tablet. Overall, it works well and she enjoys it, what more could one ask for?

Our son loves it; he get's it taken away for being to rough with it but this is certainly a quality piece because it still works perfectly. Makes for a great car companion when we have more than just a short drive to take.

We have two other Leappads (A Leap Pad 1 and a Monsters Univ. Bundle Leap Pad 2).  The Doc McStuffins LeapPad 2 Power Bundle is my favorite and in my opinion the best value.  This bundle includes a battery recharger and AC adapter, which is worth its weight in gold (actual value: $40).  It also includes a $20 download card for the LeapFrog store, two extra styli (one purple, one pink) as well as a USB cord.

We already have a variety of games and eBook cartridges (Cinderella, Bubble Guppies, Dora, Phineas and Ferb, iSpy, Jake and Neverland Pirates, etc). The downlard card can be used in LeapFrog AppCenter to purchase games, ebooks and videos.  Browsing content and uploading to the LeapPad is simple.  You can install the same content on multiple LeapPads in your family.  We've mostly purchased videos such as episodes of Dora and Bubble Guppies for restaurants and car rides.  The drawing app that comes with the LeapPad is also a favorite of my daughter.

Setup is relatively simple using LeapFrog Connect software.  The features that the LeapPad 2 adds above the original Leappad is a front-facing camera, more memory (4 GB vs 2 GB) and better battery life.  The LeapPad 2 Power adds the battery recharger and AC adapter but is otherwise the same product.  (Though this bundle comes with 2 extra styli and usually you get 1 extra).

Let me tell you, the included battery recharger is worth its weight in gold!  The Leap Pad 1 drains batteries and the battery case was difficult to open (had to use stylus or a penny).  The Leappad 2 adds a better batter compartment, but the LeapPad 2 power includes the battery recharger... it's easy to use and lasts about 8 hours of use.  It can be recharged using the AC adapter without having the remove the batteries from the compartment.  In an "emergency" you could still swap out the battery recharger for four AA batteries (regular or rechargeable), but with the longer battery life, this should not be needed in everyday use.

The Doc McStuffins design is very cute - my 4 year old daughter is a huge fan of the show.  The Amazon frustration free packaging made it easy to open and get started.  No clamshell or excess packaging, just a few cardboard separators and a few twist ties for the cords.  The batteries came with some charge and you can set up the LeapPad right out of the box.  You can create a profile for up to 3 children on the same device, plus a "Guest" user.  However, to use any of the content you must first hook to the LeapFrog Connect Application via a computer.  If you are giving this as a gift and you know your child will want to check it out right away, you could set it up and put it back into the box without much trouble.

Overall, the LeapPad 2 Power is a great product for kids age 3-9.  Some of the apps are a little challenging for my 4 year old, but she will grow into the device with time.  I don't have to worry about durability or her breaking it.  It's nice and solid, her LeapPad (original) is still going strong (though no longer used often since we've upgraded due to better battery life on the LeapPad 2s). This is a great educational product from LeapFrog and there is a nice variety of content available for early learning.

We've had this for a year and a half now so I can be fair in accessing the device.  The device itself is pretty durable both in terms of build quality and operating stability.  It is a heavy and clunky device however,  and it does not compare well to any sort of android or ipod.  The screen is resistive and not capacitative.  I.e., it needs a LOT of finger pressure or needs the stylus. Also,  the bezel is enormous compared to the relatively small screen.  All this is really of secondary importance if you're kid is not used to using your $600 iPad.

The big issue is the cost of apps and the horrible interface with your computer (to uoload and download data ).  I'll address each of these.

The apps are a lot more expensive than anything you'll see on the App Store or Google Play.  The cheapest is $5 and a lot of them are $20 or $25!!!  And as a parent you're expected to add perhaps 10 or 20 of these.  Thats a lot of cake!

And a lot of the apps or games are much less sophisticated than free apps on a phone or ipad.  The educational value is rather limited... probably greater educational value than game apps commonly available,  but for the money,  I do not feel like we're getting a good value here.  You even have to pay for an app that allows you to load mp3 tunes so your kid can listen to music.  And it's a very poor app at that which will not even allow songs to be selected individually.  Your kid has to start at song number one and proceed from there... you cannot sort by album or artist as you can on the most primitive mp3 player.

Lastly,  the software on your PC or Mac that you'll need to load from the company website is called Connect.  It sucks. It's clunky,  requires frequent "updates " from the company which you MUST accept.  The synching process can take ages,  it loses connection to the LeapPad and is generally primitive.  Carefully consider this because as the parent,  YOU will be doing this.

We bought the original LeapPad when it first came out. It was a pain to use because it took a long time to stat up, had a rather poor screen, and, worst of it all, the Leapfrog Connect software was absolutely terrible.

This new version has improved every aspect, and the newer versions of Leapfrog Connect software (which I believe only runs on Windows, which is a bummer as my main computers are Macs, but do own a couple of PCs which unfortunately run the much hated Windows 8/8.1).  What has not improved is they still seem to use USB 1 as the connector, for it takes a long time to download software (apps, ebooks, videos or music) to the Leap Pad 2.  LeapFrog is apparently moving away from the cartridge model.  Even though this LeapPad still has a cartridge slot, it's hard to find LeapPad cartridges in stores or on Amazon.com.  Instead, apparently they expect you to download all software via LeapFrog Connect.

Here's a money-saving tip:  you can buy the $20 LeapFrog download card for about 5 bucks off here on Amazon.com.  LeapFrog also has frequent discount codes, for example, currently you can use CELEBRATE to achieve tiered discount savings.

Hardware-wise, LeapPad2 is solidly built. It's easy to hold by kids -- at least that what mine told me. the 5-inch screen has a resolution of 480x272, lower than that on the Nintendo 3DS, but okay for education-oriented games.  It comes with 4GB of built-in storage memory. But it does not have an SD or micro SD slot for additional memory, so your kid should not transfer too much video or audio or photos to it. It has two separate low-resolution cameras, one on front and one on back.

While the screen is okay in pixel density, especially for the target audience, its brightness and contrast cannot be adjusted, unlike the old LeapFrog Explorer or Leapster, for example. Worse, it still uses resistive touch technology, so it doesn't work well with fingers. Instead, you're expected to use the attached stylus. Here the stylus is literally attached via a lanyard to the side of the LeapPad2, and there's a little indented holder for the stylus, but it's a crude solution.  A stylus slot would have been a much better feature, so the stylus wouldn't fall out of place frequently.

LeapFrog's learning apps are okay. They suffer from a serious lack of depth across the board -- and they ain't really cheap. A typical app costs 10 dollars each. Some audio books cost 10 or the more interactive ones cost 25! (C.f. half that much for interactive Nook ebooks or much, much better-made ebooks on the iPad.)  I actually paid for a few additional apps to the ones that came with the review unit. While my kids enjoyed a couple of them, they finished all the levels within a day or two.  Not the best 20 bucks I've spent.  I get much better values out of iPad kids' apps; even free iPad kids apps have longer play time.

The LeapFrog Connect software, which you need in order to download apps and other files (and to make the LeapPad2 really work, otherwise it keeps reminding you to connect to the PC), is much improved. Gone are mysterious disconnects and vanishing files or cryptic error codes that even LeapFrog's support couldn't help me with.  A couple of times it still failed to download purchased contents to the LeapPad2 on first try, but a disconnect and reconnect of the USB cable solved the problem immediately. Now, notice that you can't charge the LeapPad2 from the USB port; you *must* use the separate AC adapter which plugs into a rounded charge port on the LeapPad2.  This unnecessarily creates an unnecessary necessity for yet another unnecessary accessory. (I hope you liked my humor.)

We thought we were being smart by purchasing this LeapPad verses the Ultra because of all the poor reviews from so many disappointed parents.  Our 6 year old showed a lot of interest when we first introduced this to him, of course he did, it was new.  However, the games for this are ridiculously over priced for what you actually get.  We would buy him a game and he either beat it or lost interest with it within a day or two.  The apps and games are also ridiculously priced, and most of the games are way...way to "generic".  They have a few Disney/Pixar themed games, but most of them are lame....sorry.  LeapPad's in general, in my opinion at least, are a major waste of money.  The video camera that is built in is horrid, all grainy and very low quality.  At best this is a possibly "OK" toy for a 3-4 year old, kids are WAY to advanced nowadays for such a limited tablet.  It's freaking incredibly annoying because it constantly repeats directions over and over again regardless of how many times you've played.  Like the art app, every 5 seconds it repeats the directions until you want to throw the thing out the window.  It's a money trap for Parent's, they keep sending all kinds of promotions to keep buying the apps and games...and very few of them are worth the money they ask for.  No...sorry, if I could I would tell anyone to stay far far away from LeapPad.  If you want a tablet that is decent, get your kid a Kindle Fire and just teach them to be responsible with it.

I love the LeapPad2, we already own one and we love the affordable downloaded games that we can add to more than on device, and this Doc McStuffins design is pretty great too. I bought this product for my 4 year old son and he loves it, every time he has it he plays it for hours we have to take from him from time to time.lol. Its a great learning/entertainment tool for long trips and so on. Really enjoyed this product

My five-year-old daughter has been wanting a Leap Pad for about six months now since she played her cousin's, so I was happy to get the opportunity to try this one.  Boy am I glad we didn't spend money on it.

The good points of this device begin and end with the ease of set up.  Out of the box, the Leap Pad will be ready to use in about ten minutes of hooking up to the internet and downloading from the Leap Frog website.

When my daughter first got the Leap Pad, she dove right into it and played most of the rest of the day, pausing only when we insisted that she give her older sister a turn to satisfy her curiosity.  I was relieved that finally she won't be pestering me for my smartphone all the time.

After playing with it again the next day for less than an hour, however, my daughter asked me for my phone again.  By the end of the week she had practically forgotten about the Leap Pad and was right back with the phone.  While giving in and letting her borrow my phone, I decided to see what this Leap Pad is all about.  Didn't take me more than 5 minutes to want my phone back.

The package includes nine apps when you initially connect to the Leap Frog website.  Among these are a decent art program, a pet corner and a game that "teaches" the flags and various random useless facts about countries the majority of adults have never heard of.  There is also a calculator, a clock and a couple other apps your average preschooler will never touch.  To the extent she has used it at all since the initial days, my daughter only uses the pet and art apps.

The package also includes a $20 download card in order to load more programs from the Leap Frog website.  At first I was pretty impressed.  The apps range from $5 and up and you get a discount the more apps you buy.  The apps include games, videos, ebooks and other sorts of "educational" material.  I was able to get five apps, so I was pretty happy.  At first the new apps didn't download to the device properly and my daughter couldn't find them, but my husband hooked the device back up to the internet and the problem resolved itself.

The problem is, the apps are junk.  The games are very simplistic and repetitive.  Among the games we got, there were two themes.  Three of the games involved inserting missing pieces to create a complete tube or waterslide to get from one end of a path to the other.  Two of the games involved patterns of moving objects out of the way to "free" something (a polar bear, for instance).  The one ebook we got was insulting, even for a preschooler's cognitive level and my daughter didn't want to touch it again.

I'm sure our mistake was choosing the cheaper alternatives.  I'm guessing that the apps that cost $20 and up may hold your child's attention better.  But who wants to spend that kind of money on a child's toy that already costs nearly $100?  It's just a continual black hole sucking money straight out of your wallet.  You can also choose cartridges which can at least be shared among friends, but they are also expensive and are probably easily lost.

Once you set up the device and register your child(ren), Leap Frog will send you periodic updates regarding your child's "progress".  This is to give further credibility to Leap Pad as an "educational learning tool".  The fact is, however, there is little that is educational about this or any other electronic gadget.  Memorizing facts is not "learning".  Age appropriate learning for a preschooler involves hands-on exploration and discovery, pretend play, engagement with parents and other adults, as well as interaction with peers.  None of that is offered - and, in fact, is stilted - by isolated, controlled "play" on a gadget.

In any case, in this modern world, electronic gadgets may be nearly unavoidable.  If you really think your youngster needs a gadget, a simple small tablet would probably be a better option.  There are plenty of free games and other apps for tablets.  It may not look as inviting and "child-friendly" as this device with its two extra styluses and Doc McStuffins wallpaper, but it's a much better deal in the long run.

Update 3/13/14:  Two other things I forgot to mention.  First, the Leap Pad is equipped with a camera, but it takes such bad pictures, your child will probably not want to use this feature more than once.  Second, on the pet app, your child can wash his/her pet which involves, among other things, blowing into part of the device to dry off the pet, which the kids think is fun, but I find a bit bizarre.  I don't know whether the germ factor bothers me more (especially since it's designed to be shared among up to three kids) or the fact that it's eerily like a breathalyzer.

My daughter loves Doc Mcstuffin, so she really loves this LeapPad. It is worth getting.

We have twin 4yo boys. This past Christmas I thought long and hard about buying a LeapFrog LeapPad2 as their big "Santa" gift. We have iPads and iPhones that we let them use occasionally, which they love, but I've always been a LeapFrog fan for the educational value, so I was very interested in this toy. I decided to just buy one and see how it went, then if they both loved it, and I liked the apps, we'd get a second so they wouldn't fight over it. Well, it's been a couple months, and I'm starting to shop for a second one! They really do love it, and I feel like the apps are good quality and educational (although on the spendy side compared to iPad apps, which are also educational). I ordered this product about one week before Christmas 2013 and it came prior to the delivery date. I received every item in the bundle package including the gift card. I purchased approximately 6 games with the gift card off the leapfrog website. It was very easy setup as well. None the less my 3 year old plays with it on a daily basis. She absolutely adores the skinz and the design of the item. I am very satisfied.

We have four kids.  My older kids all had Leapsters and I'm a big fan of LeapFrog and their products.  However, I think they need to realize that they can't charge $25 for an app these days, when my kids can buy an app for their Kindle Fire or iPad for 99 cents.  I understand that cartridges used to be $20, but the market has moved on.  I also hated that I had to hook up the LeapPad to my computer via a USB cable to update anything.  The advantages of the LeapPad is it's much more durable than a typical tablet (not sure compared to the Nabi, and the LeapFrog games have been tested and perfected for years.  My kids love playing the gamesbut more than the other apps? I can't say that.

I loved (and my daughter loved) the Doc McStuffins design.  It's adorable.  The LeapPad is pretty easy to set up.  You have to put the rechargeable batteries in (put the square like tab in firstthen the cylinder)and charge it, before connecting it to your computer to download the 9 free apps.  The $20 card it came with is great, but once again, with the price of the apps, you can still end up shelling out $5 for a lot of apps, or might get one to download without additional money.

Once again, I'm a big fan of their products, but I don't see that this is any better than the Kindle Fire with FreeTime we have for the kids, or even a regular iPad.  The price point for the LeapPad is less, but with the $30 off deals for KindleFire, and the Prime deal on Free Time which gives you new monthly content for your kids, you'll end up saving long term.

If LeapFrog dropped the price on their apps, nothing should be more than $9.99, and most should be under $5.00, then I'd give it five stars.  But with the price of the apps today, I can't.

My 4 and 6 year old have enjoyed this tablet. The whole package was fantastic. I really love the rechargeable battery pack that came with it. We go through lots of batteries and this was a life and money saver. The interchangeable wallpaper made my kid feel like she had a computer like "mommies". The extra stylus and charger were a must and it makes this purchase all the better. I would highly recommend this bundle to anyone looking to get their kid a tablet. You end up having to buy so many extras that don't come with the tablet alone and in the end you've spent to much for a kid's toy. LeapFrog LeapPad2 Power is the tablet to buy for any kid.
my son loves it, a very good product open to a lot of options and very good games and educative activities
My wife and I love it  also my 5year old son who Just won't stop playing  with, he Just loves to take pictures and make videos  it keeps him busy thumps up .

My toddlers 2/4 have started out with these Leap Pad's for several years now. I have invested over $500 in Aps and seen them play continuously. I've used them at ER visits, sick days, traveling and everyday learning adventures. The key to my success, I regulate time and work side by side interacting with my child through difficult skill levels and the unit itself challenges them to strive high. Educating myself and playing the pad with them empowers them to learn and grow. My relationship educationally has grown to higher limits utilizing the program. The games have age levels indicated on the product and using the App Center. If you use your own Tablet you might run into a problem not knowing the best age requirement or skill set best for your child. Your child might get discouraged playing them at higher levels then what's intended. Hate to see them frustrated or even break your expensive phone/pad. The better educational programs seem to run better on home pc's then purchasing them in an app format. Company's are still working out app formats for their product. You might just receive partial availability. Where Leap Frog you get the BEST of all! Evaluating the graphic's, may not be the best at times but the Leap Pad 2 my toddlers are attaining the concepts. The durability I've experienced was at the hardware store and my child dropped it 6 ft up. No gel cover, it never broke and it rebooted itself. I was surprised it's REALLY kid proof. I danced for joy! Down loading through the Connect has been difficult, sometimes it cuts off through the down loads. Be prepared to wait. I've realized spending money on the big brand names had no effect when considering the smaller less costlier games. They love them all. Invest in extra reusable batteries, especially if you like music. Box indicate 9 hrs of play, you'll be lucky to get half that time. BEST of All if you have more then one child you only have to purchase the games once, down loading them all to multiple pads saving you cash. The app center runs specials all the time. Each child can play the same game, different units now. Your toddler may try to pull out the games while in play, damaging it if you buy from toy stores. Buy from the app center is your best bang for the buck! At Christmas stores reduce the cost, take advantage of those specials preparing for high skill games and ebooks. Thank you for taking the time to read

it only comes with 1 free game, then you have to buy the rest. they are more expensive than the ipad apps. it's ridiculous! not worth it for the price you pay! better to buy an ipad mini or something similar. there are tons of free apple games you can download too. would not recommend this!

My two-year-old son got this for Christmas and he loves it. LeapFrog suggests it for I think 3-5 year olds, but my son is pretty smart for his age. He loves to read the stories in the games too...well...listen to me read them. But he has a blast with it and it's certainly more educational than most of the TV shows he likes.

We are huge fans of all things LeapFrog. Our children have grown up with a variety of LeapFrog handhelds and other devices that have served them well in teaching them reading and math, and even logic and reasoning skills. I love the effortlessness of the games and education. Education should be fun and should be rewarding: it sets children up with a lifelong love of reading and learning.

This is the second of our themed LeapPad2s and this is another winner. These colors are a welcome change to the longstanding green or pink variations - which really were a sad selection of colors - oh, and before that, the white didjes. Our first Bundled set was LeapFrog LeapPad2 Disney/Pixar Monsters University Varsity Edition Bundle and it is just gorgeous. It even has little horns on the top of the gel skin featuring Mike.

I like these bundle packages especially. The value to them is better than buying the parts, separately of course. The included battery pack is also a great improvement to these devices. The battery pack is a game changer.

Once you set this LeapPad2 up with the basic info and connect it to your computer, the update should happen pretty quickly. Mine didn't take a full minute. It downloads the apps: Learning Songs, Art Studio, Clock, Calendar, NotePad and calendar and one app you choose from the 3 offered. Every time I have set a LeapPad up lately, I have been offered a discount based on how many apps I buy, up to 30% off from 3 or more. This deal is far better than the discounts that come in emails and I try to make sure I take advantage of them, even using my extra digital download cards to stock up.

Multiple device app downloads: For a long time, you needed to purchase one app for each device, unless you ordered the game cartridges. LeapFrog has become a lot more reasonable lately. With these more recent LeapPad 2s and Ultras we are now able to purchase an app once and download it on up to three devices. This was a long time coming but they certainly made me appreciate it when it happened. There is something of a guessing game that goes on when I run up against a usage limit on one of the apps and then have to find which device it is on. This has happened to us with Stretchy Monkey, Reef Builder, Letter Factory, Elements on the Loose, Scooby Doo Spelling, and Disney Planes. These have been the favorite apps, by far. It is still better than only being able to download one app to one device.

You can buy download cards on Amazon at various prices. I keep them in my shopping cart and watch the prices. The lowest I had ever seen was at $14, except for one brief shining moment. But when you combine these cards with the discounts you will get through emails, they can bring the price of apps down significantly. I buy them on sale and then wait until I hook up a new device so that I get the first hookup discount. :D

Another thing that I love as a teacher, a parent, and a grandparent, is how responsive LeapFrog is to suggestions and requests by parents and teachers.

This was the second LeapPad I have purchased and both had the same issue. After falling a short distance (arm of couch onto carpet floor) the screen literally shattered. I gave 3 stars because after e-mailing leapfrog and complaining about their lack of quality and durability for something marketed towards younger children, they mailed me a new one, all it cost was shipping the broken one back to them. If the replacement breaks I will not be buying a new one anytime soon and possibly not ever. They do make great games and it is a great product for kids but it should not shatter so easily.

Dellarese Lightbourn

My parents purchased this for Christmas for my daughter. They insisted on registering it on their computer which meant any time I wanted to load more games on the device I had to go over to  their house.  That was most likely the idea...whatever.  Three weeks after Christmas my daughter was getting out of the car and dropped it about 2.5 feet which cracked the screen.  I contacted Leap Frog and they said they don't replace cracked screens but this time they would make an exception...if I sent it to them on my own dime they would return me a new one.  A month later I received the new one...without any batteries!  I called them to ask where my batteries were and they said they would forward my complaint to the "correct department" and they would get back to me.  That was a week ago and I am beginning to think I will have to pay $40 for a new battery or accept I have an expensive doorstop.

Instead of purchasing this 5" screen with expensive content, purchase a 7" screen tablet with a warranty for broken screens for the same price.  Instead of paying for overpriced content that can't be re-sold with the device you can have a better device with nearly unlimited free games, music and video with Amazon Prime.  Honestly, I don't know how this company stays in business.

3/1/14
After two frustrating calls and two weeks I received the batteries.  They are not the new batteries I sent, but I now have the battery holders that I can put new batteries in to run the device.  Now I just have to take an afternoon off to get to my parents house to download the apps that they purchased.  Hopefully the device will last longer than it did initially.  I'll let you know.

Update.
The rechargeable batteries they returned won't hold a charge for more than 15 minutes.  There are so many options for devices that work and don't charge for kids games.  Don't purchase this product.

This may look like a tablet but don't be fooled. I am not going to give it a bad review but am only going to compare it to Innotab 2 which I had returned in order to get this for my three year old.

What makes this deal seem interesting is that they give you a 20 dollar card to spend on their market. Let me repeat, their market! Unlike the Innotab 2, which allows you to youtube, upload music and movies, and other things similar to what a typical tablet will do (bare minimum), the Leap Pad 2 allows only their products which are pretty expensive. I must add though, if you get two or more games, videos etc from their website, they will give you a discount. But these games are still 25 a pop. And none free to get either which is ridiculous. That means no outside parties are allowed to add anything to this monopolized market they call the Leap Pad store.

However faster than the Innotab 2 with a way better camera, that doesn't compensate for the lack of stuff I can do on an Leappad2. Granted, my 3 year old gives a crap about stuff and more about Mickey Mouse!!! So my problem is a daddy issue and not a kid issue. I have to admit, I either want the Innotab 2 back just for more versatility (so slow though), or I want something in between these two devices.

The 20 dollar gift card did get me a couple items only because they give you a discount. Just remember, Innotab 2 lets you do whatever but horrible camera and speeds while Leappad 2 gives you NO VERSATILITY but decent camera and decent speeds. Good luck!

We like the educational benefit of the leap frog. We purchased for our 3 year grandson in effort to get him started on technology and reinforce some basic principles that he is being taught every day in his classroom.

This device is locked down for money generating purposes by LeapFrog. By the time anyone puts a few apps on it or buys a couple of cartridges, they will have spent the same amount as they could have on a kindle fire HD 7". Put a few more on and you've covered the cost of the otterbox cover for the kindle fire HD 7" as well. Want to put your own media on this device? That will cost you as you have to buy an app for that. Want to do anything other than the basics that are included? That will cost you money. The kindle has access to many free apps that will not cost you any money and are great for kids. I do like how durable the LeapPad2 is as it can take some abuse, but so can a kindle with the right protective case. My child got bored with this is less than a month since he was also exposed to a kindle at nearly the same time. To recap, if you plan on putting as few as 10 apps on the LeapPad2 you will have spent what the kindle fire HD 7" costs. Also, my son was able to scratch the screen on the first day of use. For a touch screen tablet designed for use by young children, this is not reassuring.

Well I have to say this one is a big flop for me! I bought it for my son, who is almost 4 years old, and I thought I strike gold. It turned out that all the applications that you have to buy from Leapfrog (only) are damn expensive. It might be the most educational tablet on the market - gosh I hope I'll never again gave in to those marketing ads - I can't say much about it right now, but with prices of 10-25 USD for every small application that your kid will use for 2-3 days tops, until he finishes all the levels, this makes me, as a parent, feel cheated and robbed. Leapfrog lost a lot of its credibility with this approach and I am pretty sure they will loose lots of customers as well. One of them is going to be me!

We got this for my son because it had good reviews and it can't go online. We have an iPad, and have used that for movies and some games, but we didn't want him to be able to do internet searches or get onto bad sites on accident. And he was starting to be able to change settings we didn't want changed - sometimes on purpose and sometimes on accident.

Pros:
Upon opening it, he immediately identified it as an iPad. We wanted something that looked similar to what we used so he'd use it more. He now loves his LeapPad and asks for it by name. This looks just like many phones with apps and tablets with apps, so it's great for him feeling like its similar.

He likes being able to explore all the apps, and I like that I don't have to worry about him messing with settings or deleting things or getting into something I don't want him in.

I like that the parent menu is not easily accessible to him but is easily accessible to me.

It seems very user friendly. My son has not been frustrated when trying to use it.

Cons:
I do not like that LeapPad automatically puts advertisements on it for my son to "learn" about and then ask for. You can disable this in the parent menu, and a quick google will help you if you should need it.

You have to purchase the mp3 player app ($5) if you want to put your own music on it. $5 is not expensive, but it's music I've already paid for on a device I've already paid for, so this was annoying.

The apps are expensive. Compared to most tablet apps today, $20-$25 is really expensive. We have not purchased any yet (other than the mp3 player), and may not till he's much older.

Also, the memory is not huge (4gigs I think) and there is no way to add memory. So it seems like it would be more space efficient to get the cartridges than to download the games and I think they are the same price.

We ordered the Doc McStuffins LeapPad for my daughter for Christmas.  We received it on time, I set it up for her so when she opened it she could use it.  The first day she used it, we inserted a game & the device did not recognize the game.  We simple shut it off & turned it back on, and it worked again.  We have 3 different games and it was working great for 2 weeks.  Now, the device will not recognize the game cartridges.  It knows when the game cartridge is not inserted, but as soon as it is inserted it shows an "X".  I've tried to find answers online & couldn't find any other than cleaning it.  I did this and still didn't work.  I emailed support and they told me to do the same thing.  Clean the games, the cartridge slot, insert the game, clean again, then turn on.  I did this with all 3 games and none are recognized. I've followed up with customer support & will see what they have to say.  We were contemplating buying a Kindle Fire or iPad mini for my daughter for Christmas, but we went with the cheaper option.  Now I wish we would have just bought a tablet for her,  she is extremely frustrated that she can't play her games now.

I have to say that I was not planning to buy a LeapPad2. My 4 and 5 year old kids have access to a laptop and an iPad, so I did not think they would be interested in this. However, my 5 year old was getting the newest Nintendo 3ds XL, and I wanted to get something electronic for my 4 year old daughter as well. Boy, was I surprised with the quality! I was very surprised by wonderful graphics, responsive touch screen and tilting capabilities, etc. I also found out that I could buy a $5 MP3 app from the leapfrog store, and download all of my mp3 music on the leappad - since my daughter enjoys music so much, getting all of her favorite songs on the leappad, and only paying for the app, made her Christmas. In addition, you can set up skills that you want your child to learn in several apps. In Tangled game, I uploaded her list of sight words that she can practice. In Roli Poli 2 game, I set it up for her to learn addition.

I was also surprised that the digital apps/games you download - can be downloaded on up to 3 devices! My 5 year old loved my 4 year old daughter's leappad so much that I ordered him a boys' bundle the same day. He now plays with his Leappad more than with his 3ds XL. And the kids can have the purchased apps on both leappads.

The LeapFrog LeapPad2 Power Learning Tablet, Green is a sturdy tablet for younger children.  Based on LeapFrogs reputation and the reviews of this tablet posted on Amazon, I purchased the LeapFrog LeapPad2 Power Learning Tablet for my four-year old grandson.  I also purchased the LeapPad get Ready for 1st Grade Game Bundle for Boys directly from LeapFrog since it was not available from Amazon.

Weighing 15.8 oz., the LeapPad2 Power Learning Tablet is sturdy enough to withstand young, enthusiastic users handling.  The 2 9/16 X 3 7/8 screen is quite small and images depicted on it are less detailed than adults might like.  However, children do seem to find the cartoon figures and graphics appealing.  Instructions included with the tablet were lacking in detail and provide little assistance when it comes to setting up the LeapPad2.  Games in the bundles I purchased are not particularly engaging.  My grandson liked watching the Cars cartridge because it included Lightening McQueen and Mater; I was less than impressed with the educational value of the cartridge.

Although my grandson loves his pad, I think a Kindle Fire HD would have been a more practical and useful choice.  It has a larger screen, the cost of the game/learning apps is less than the price of LeapFrog cartridges; and the support for Kindle is far superior to LeapFrogs.  If you are looking for a sturdy tablet for younger children, you may want to consider the LeapFrog LeapPad2 Power Learning Tablet.  If you are looking for a functional, useful tablet and will be using it with your little one, then I definitely recommend you purchase a Kindle Fire HD instead.  I wish I had done so.

Hello- This is a writeup about my first impressions about the LeapPad2. They're in bullet for easy review.

- More complicated than it needs to for a child- I was surprised at the number of decisions and that after almost every decision, the user needs to hit the check box. This creates a lot of unnecessary steps to get going. Example: Let's say I choose the Art application. I should be able to just get going and start drawing. Nope. I have to tap the app, hit a check box after the introduction, then select a 'tool', then am forced to select a color, then tap the check box, then I can draw. WOW. A child should just tap the art app, and start drawing. This is for a toddler, it doesn't need to be this complicated.

- This still requires a Stylus. This caused great frustration and confusion for my 3yr old. She is accustomed to starting up the iPad and just getting going with her fingers. She hates the stylus and doesn't want to use it (I can relate). The 1990s called, they'd like they're stylus back.

- No built in WiFi. You have to do everything teathered to your computer. Updates take forever and like bullet point 1, there are a lot of uncessary steps to get the device registed. Once registered, its all about buying more apps. Buy Buy Buy.. We get it.. you need to sell apps. Ok. I'll do it, but this is a pretty inconvenient way to do so.

- There is no way to tell how charged your battery is. I can't find it anywhere. How do I know if its fully charged before I get on an airplane. On that note, there's no settings anywhere such as brightness, etc I don't expect a child to care, but a parent does. If they are using it in the dark, it would be nice to turn down the brightness so it doesn't burn my kids eyes.

- On the plus side, there are a lot of videos and apps to choose from and its nice that LeapFrog doesn't have the bottomless pit of problems that In-App purchases creates. Bravo LeapFrog. Thank you!

- Our 3yr old is having problems getting going on it (compared to so naturally on the iPad), but once she's going, she seems to really like it. Everything on here is about learning and exploring which is great.

My advice to LeapFrog Ditch the expensive COGS of another pad device, and just make terrific application for computers and devices (Pads, Phones, and Computers). LeapFrog is in very very sharky waters trying to compete in the pad market. Your apps are great, but the devices are jus ok.

If it had been purchased from them, they claim they will do a one-time replacement, but I'm not so sure. From what I've read and experienced, their customer service is very poor. Though my daughter liked it, I'm very hesitant to buy a another unit if they are so easily destroyed. So disappointed! One other note: the screen is easily scratched and marked. You will need to buy some kind of screen protector.

Update: Though Leapfrog customer service is totally unhelpful, Leapfrog's facebook page contacted me within minutes after I left this review on their page. They said they would work with me, gave me instructions, and before the end of the day, there was a new Leappad in the mail. We received it about eight days later. Though they said the warranty doesn't cover accidents, they replaced the device as a one-time courtesy. From now on, the new pad is tethered to a table to ensure against any more drops.

I cannot believe the positive reviews on the LeapPad 2.  We received one as a Christmas gift for my toddler and were really excited to give it a try after reading all of the rave reviews.  Unfortunately, this device is a huge disappointment and a very poor value.  The 8 pre-loaded apps are essentially garbage.  One free app download is included, but you only have 3 very basic apps to choose from, and only one of the three is rated for children under the age of 5.  The apps run $10-$20 which is obscene considering you can buy excellent ipad  apps for $0.99 for pretty much any age child.  The display is very low quality and connecting it to a PC to download apps is laughable even for a $100 tablet.  Considering you could easily pony up $300 between the tablet and a half dozen apps, you could buy a Kindle Fire, Android, or even older iPad for a comparable price and have 100x the versatility.  The LeapPad 2 is headed straight back to Amazon.  Every alternative tablet is a better value for really any age child.

I have an engineering background and this is a terrible design.
-Screen broke on first day from being dropped once, while in a protective gel case and in the padded zipper carry case.
If the screen breaks that easily, watch out.

How it happened:  Parent placed Leap Pad in protective gel case, then placed in the Leap Pad padded case made specifically for the Leap Pad.  The gel case makes it a slightly more snug fit, but that isn't the design problem.  One game was placed in the lid as designed.  My child dropped it once and screen was broken.
--The lip of the games is a perfect stress-point that directly impacts the edge of the glass.

This is one parent very frustrated that I buy two protective items for the particular device and it is still broken on the first day.
LeapFrog voided the warranty and is going to send me a replacement Leap Pad after I ship this one back to them at my cost.
Their design problems caused the break.  Not a happy camper.
My 3 year old loves it! Perfect for toddlers to listen to music, color & listen to stories. The $20 certificate is perfect to help parents chose which educational apps work best for their child.

Pay the extra few dollars and get your child a Kindle. For Christmas I got my 5 and 7 year old Kindle's but thought the Kindle would be too advanced for my 3 year old so I bought him the Leap Frog Leap Pad 2.  This device was a waste of money.  First of all I had to download a bunch of software from the Leap Frog website onto my computer (how lame is that?).  If I wanted kids stuff on my computer I wouldn't have purchased a Leap Frog Pad, I would've just let him use my computer. The screen and graphics are about as bad as a first generation Nintendo Game boy. The Kindle has a program for kids that has the ability to be much better for learning and has way more features than the Leap Frog. This technology on the Leap Frog pad is very far behind and really shouldn't be for how much they cost (this thing is expensive).

I have no qualms about the quality of this device.  My 4yo absolutely loves it.  She picked tight up on how to use the apps, take pictures, etc.  The apps and games are well chosen and focused on learning abilities.  However, the included content is severely limited (even though this is a 9-app bundle).  The "included apps" are things most people take for granted: a note-taking app, a music player (that does not support your own MP3s, and includes only one set of songs) and a "camera app" for a camera-equipped device.  Other "extra" features include the (very basic and altogether necessary) ability to charge the tablet by plugging it into an AC outlet.  The real problem, though, is when you want to buy more content.  Let's say you want the music to a favorite animated film.  Would you pay $10 for a measly 4 songs and a narrated story?  I did, and rightly felt robbed.  This device is, in fact, the most flagrant highway robbery since the invention of the $100 printer with $20 cartridges.  The Leappad2 itself is inexpensive and highly attractive, the included content well curated but extremely limited.  When you want to buy a game that would cost you $3 in an Android app store, with Leapfrog you fork up $10-20.  In the end, getting this $90 dollar tablet up to speed with a minimal amount of content set me back a total of $150.

My advice, bottom line: buy a Kindle with FreeTime and stay clear of this pint-sized money pit.  I certainly wish I had.

I acquired the Doc McStuffins iteration of this product for my 3 year old daughter.  My daughter is autistic and developmentally delayed.  She has played some games on it, watched videos, listened to music and "read" a book.  Her older brother and sister got a Nook e-ink and a Kindle e-ink reader for Christmas and my littlest one loves that she can "read" like her bubby and sissy.

I was concerned about the durability, as anyone who has an autistic child knows that if they lose their patience, things can go flying.  This has been dropped and sat on a couple of times today and is still holding steady.  I was concerned when I saw some of the complaints about the screen durability, but I think we will be okay.

My daughter loves that some of her favorite characters can come to life in her hands.  She loves that she can watch her videos on it and listen to music and dance.  She had fun playing with the camera and taking pictures of herself and everyone else and it fell asleep watching one of her favorites, Super Why! on it this evening.

The app/game prices are a little spendy, and I wish you had the option of adding your own videos to the device, but I understand that older models did not even allow for loading your own music, so maybe the video option is something that will come with time.  The loading your own videos and books is the only advantage I see the Innotab having right now.

I wish the app that were age appropriate for my 3 year old were priced a little lower.  I also wish that there were more game options for the 3-5 range, as I feel that that age range is underserved an most of what is available for them is videos.  But despite that, my daughter got several hours of enjoyment out of this on the first day and I anticipate that this will be her new favorite toy.  She is obsessed with My Little Pony and received MANY ponies for Christmas, and they sit in the pile neglected as she has not wanted to put down her "KindleNook" as she calls it.
I like the size; the design is very strong and easy to use for children my girl is only two and she like it at lot.

We couldn't be more pleased.  We purchased Leap Pad 2 for our young granddaughter.  It's the perfect beginners tablet for todays youngsters.  There are enough apps included to keep them interested and craving for more.

Whats not to like, once mastered other apps are readily available.  Children today are so advanced, many are more than ready for school.  The Re-Charger Battery Pack, AC Adapter, Music Player, and Art Studio were great enhancements, it solidified our decision to purchase.

Avoid LeapFrog products at all cost.  You think you save money or time, but they have the worst customer service in the world.  I am writing this review after spending nearly 2 hours with customer service, with them unable to explain why the $5 app I purchased was not syncing to my device.  However, they refused to refund me $5 even though I never got the app and they wasted hours of my time.  They say they have an absolute no refund policy  NO MATTER WHAT.  Tells you what kind of company you are dealing with.  Also, FYI, my son loves to draw, by they have virtually no art apps.  Like half a dozen, most of which involve tracing letters or shapes, and are totally redundant.  And they all cost like $20.  So whatever you think you save on the purchase of this cheap kids tablet, you will spend on apps since they start at $10 and go past $20.  You may as well spend $100-$200 more for an iPad or Android tablet where you can get literally dozens or hundreds of art apps, learning apps, ,etc, many for free, and others for a buck or two, and much higher quality,  This thing is both a time and money pit, and the company lacks decency or scruples and should be avoided like the plague.

We bought 2 of these for my daughters; ages 3 and 6, for road trip from Houston, Texas to Arizona. In addition to the pads I bought each girl a game. Between the programs included on the pad and the additional games my girls were completely entertained for the 2 day trip.

The best things for us were:
The battery life is excellent lasted the girls the entire day. (Of course it didn't run continuously as we had several stops.)
The girls used the camera to take pictures of the sights and one another. They LOVE having the cameras and use them a lot even now.
We purchased the gel skins for them and with those on the pads are extremely durable. They were dropped and stepped on and are still going strong.
It's been over a month and they still get daily use. (That's more than I can say for several things they've received!) We've only just now purchased one new game per girl to keep them entertained.

I feel like these were a great investment. Awesome for long car trips, downtime at home, and anywhere you want to keep little ones entertained. I would buy them over and over again.
